\begin{document}

\maketitle
\tableofcontents
\phantomsection\label{index::doc}


Welcome to Flask's documentation.  This documentation is divided into
different parts.  I recommend that you get started with
{\hyperref[installation:installation]{\emph{Installation}}} and then head over to the {\hyperref[quickstart:quickstart]{\emph{Quickstart}}}.

Flask depends on two external libraries: the \href{http://jinja.pocoo.org/2/}{Jinja2} template
engine and the \href{http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/}{Werkzeug} WSGI toolkit.  These libraries are not documented
here.  If you want to dive into their documentation, check out the
following links:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\href{http://jinja.pocoo.org/2/documentation/}{Jinja2 Documentation}

\item {} 
\href{http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/documentation/}{Werkzeug Documentation}

\end{itemize}


\chapter{User's Guide}
\label{index:user-s-guide}\label{index:werkzeug}\label{index:meet-sphinxit}
This part of the documentation, which is mostly prose, begins with some
background information about Flask, then focuses on step-by-step
instructions for web development with Flask.


\section{Installation}
\label{installation:installation}\label{installation::doc}\label{installation:id1}
Flask depends on two external libraries, \href{http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/}{Werkzeug} and \href{http://jinja.pocoo.org/2/}{Jinja2}.
Werkzeug is a toolkit for WSGI, the standard Python interface between web
applications and a variety of servers for both development and deployment.
Jinja2 renders templates.


\section{Quickstart}
\label{quickstart::doc}\label{quickstart:quickstart}\label{quickstart:id1}
Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
{\hyperref[installation:installation]{\emph{Installation}}} section.

A minimal Flask application looks something like this:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{flask} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Flask}
\PYG{n}{app} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Flask}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n+nd}{@app.route}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{/}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{hello\PYGZus{}world}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{Hello World!}\PYG{l+s}{'}

\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{app}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

Just save it as \emph{hello.py} (or something similar) and run it with your Python
interpreter.  Make sure to not call your application \emph{flask.py} because this
would conflict with Flask itself.
